tip.title: ** The Patch Manager is DEPRECATED **
tip.para: In CodeX version 2.4 and above, the Patch Manager has been discontinued. It is now replaced by the CodeX Tracker Service (see ). This chapter is included in the CodeX User Guide for projects that originally used the legacy Patch Manager.

section.title: How To Submit Source Code Contribution
section.para: CodeX gives you an unparalleled ability to learn from the source code of others by making source code sharing a common practice at &SYS_ORG_NAME;. When you re-use a piece of code from CodeX, the Code eXchange Policy specifies that any modification you've made to the original source code must be returned to the original team.
This is the role of the Patch Manager to facilitate this process. The Patch Manager allows for:

step.para: The submission of source code modifications by CodeX users
The management of these submissions by the project team

section.para: On how to generate source code patches see the CVS chapter ().

para.emphasis: A note to the project team

note.para: Receiving source code modifications or other contributions from other CodeX users does not imply that you have to accept the new code and insert it in your main source tree. It is up to the project team to decide what to do with it. One of the interesting features of the Patch Manager is that submitted patches are available to anybody at all time regardless of the final decision of the project team. Therefore any CodeX visitor is free to download any submitted patch and apply it onto its own version of the software even if the project team has decided not to apply the patch on the main source tree.

section.title: Patch Browsing

para.emphasis: Audience: project members and CodeX users

section.para: To access the Patch Manager select the "Patches" item from the Project Menu at the top of the screen of the Project Summary page. The welcome page of the Patch Manager allows you to browse all the patches that have been submitted to this project.
Patches can be selected by Assignee, Status and Category.

listitem.para: Assignee: this is the name of the project member in charge of this specific patch
Status: status of the patch. It is one of:
Open: the patch has been submitted and is being processed by the project team
Deleted: the project team rejected the patch. It is marked as deleted but it is still visible to the CodeX users and it can be downloaded
Closed: the patch was integrated in the main source tree.
Postponed: patch considered interesting but integration in the main source tree is postponed

Category: project administrators can define categories for patches. Classifying patches in various categories makes patch selection and browsing easier. The categories generally correspond to high-level modules or functionalities of the software.

section.para: The Patch Manager menu offers 2 shortcuts to quickly select all patches with status value at Open ("Open Patches" link) and those that have been assigned to you ("My Patches" link). This is mostly for project members.
To download a patch, click on the Patch ID number in the first column of the result list () and then click on the "View raw patch" link in the next screen.

section.title: Patch Submission

para.emphasis: Audience: project members and CodeX users

section.para: In most cases, registered users who are not part of the project team submit source code patches. However this service can also be used by the project members if, for some reason, they were not granted write access to the CVS repository.
Before you submit a patch you must first generate it. This has been discussed in the CVS chapter. For more information please refer to section .

To submit a patch, click on the "Submit a Patch" item in the Patch Manager menu bar (see ). Give a one-line description in the "Summary" field. Please be accurate. Then choose a category (if any) and then attach the patch. Attaching the patch can either be done by pasting the source code of the patch in the HTML form or by using the upload facility. To validate the submission click on the "Submit Patch" button at the end of the screen.

section.title: Patch Processing
section.para: To process submitted patches, first use the Patch Browsing facility to select the patches you are interested in and click on the Patch ID number in the first column of the result list ().

listitem.para: Assigning new incoming patches to project members for evaluation and recommendation on what to do with it and when
Changing the status of the patch as the project team makes progress in the evaluation of the contributed code.
Changing the Category and possibly the Summary to better reflect the nature of the contribution (optional)
Adding a follow-up comment to the patch (e.g. why it is a good one, when to include it into the source code or in which release of the software it has been integrated...)
You can also submit a new version of the patch thus overriding the old one.

section.para: Don't forget to click on the "Submit Changes" button to validate your modifications.

section.title: E-mail Notification
section.para: Like other CodeX services the CodeX Patch Manager is equipped with an e-mail notification system. The e-mail notification system follows very simple rules. Each time a patch is submitted or updated - whether with an additional follow-up comment, with a change in any of the patch field or with a new version of the patch - an e-mail notification is sent to the following people:

listitem.para: The patch submitter (the person who initially submitted the patch)
The patch assignee (the project member to whom the patch is assigned)

The e-mail addresses specified in the "Other Configuration Settings" screen of the Patch Administration module (see ). These e-mail addresses can be any email address you want including a distribution list that was created with the CodeX Mailing List manager (see ) or via MS-Exchange.

section.para: The e-mail notification consists of the Patch ID number, Summary, Category and Status plus all follow-up comments sorted by date (most recent first).

section.title: Patch Manager Administration
section.para: Project members that have been granted Administrative rights on the Patch Manager can configure the Patch Manager in a number of ways.

section.title: Defining Categories
section.para: The Patch Manager allows you to define Patch categories. These categories can be used to characterize the nature of the patch when it is submitted. To add or delete Patch categories click on the "Admin" item in the Patch Manager menu at the top of the screen ().

section.title: Other Configuration Settings
section.para: This Patch Manager configuration module allows you to define the following configuration parameters:

listitem.para: An introductory message that we'll show up at the top of the Patch submission form. This is a convenient way to give directions and recommendations to the patch submitter. The text must use HTML tags for formatting which gives a great flexibility to shape the content of this preamble (you can use bold, italic, embed URL...)

A series of comma separated email addresses to which new patch submission and patch updates will be sent. If you want a (group of) person to be systematically aware of new item submission you can add his/her e-mail address in this text field. Checking the "Send on all updates" check box will cause e-mail notification to be sent on all updates in addition to the initial submission.
